posts.title: Post-Election Uncertainty: 20 Books You Can Count on: Accessible Version with BARD & Bookshare Links
posts.text: Most of the books on the list are available in one or more accessible formats.

posts.title: NYPL's 2020 Election Reading List: Accessible Version with BARD & Bookshare Links
posts.text: The books on this list illuminate voting issues including healthcare, education, climate change, and foreign policy, and explore subjects including political polarization, the media, and movements toward greater justice and socioeconomic equity. Most of these title are available in one or more accessible formats.

posts.title: Trans, Nonbinary and GNC Voices to Help you Celebrate Pride
posts.text: More than 200 stories of trans and gender non-conforming lives.

posts.title: Feast Your Ears on Audiobooks, Audio Magazines, Concerts, Classic Radio, and More to Keep You Busy If You Don't Read Standard Print
posts.text: For anyone—registered with us or not—there are great options.

posts.title: 125 Books We Love in Accessible Formats
posts.text: Almost all of the books on the 125 Books We Love list are available from the Andrew Heiskell Library in talking books and/or braille and on our free app.

posts.title: Early Literacy Resources for Kids with Low or No Vision
posts.text: Discover many easily learnable, shareable ways to adapt your early literacy campaign to be more inclusive.

posts.title: Announcing Bookshare: A New Partnership for Accessible eBooks!
posts.text: NYPL is proud to announce a new partnership with Bookshare, making 370,000 accessible e-books free to patrons with print disabilities.

posts.title: Making an Accessible Accessibility Resource Fair at the Andrew Heiskell Library
posts.text: Andrew Heiskell Library hosted the first Technology, Culture, and Community Fair for People who are Blind, Visually Impaired, or Physically Disabled,  welcoming 32 vendors, 16 featured speakers, and over 200 attendees.

posts.title: September Reader's Den: Predictably Irrational by Dan Ariely, Part 2
posts.text: Excerpts, discussion questions and suggestions for further reading based on Predictably Irrational.

posts.title: September Reader's Den: Predictably Irrational by Dan Ariely, Part 1
posts.text: I often find myself amazed by how weird humans are, so I appreciate books that prove we're all nuts. In the interest of sharing these hilarious, intriguing, and helpful case studies, this month I will be leading the Reader's Den in discussing the book Predictably Irrational, by Dan Ariely.

posts.title: Author interview with Teri Kanefield: Giving a long-forgotten civil rights heroine her day
posts.text: "...A teenager took control of the situation when adults couldn't..."

posts.title: Sparrows and Heroes, or Why Poetry?
posts.text: After the winter we've had, I've been really looking forward to April.  With the longer daylight hours, signs of green, and chances to enjoy the city's parks and rivers without shivering, I feel something in my brain waking up and it seems natural to break out the poetry.

posts.title: In Praise of Odd Children's Books
